item.title: Week Ten: Honesty
item.dc:creator: Brian Weatherson
item.description: We continue our look at individual virtues with a discussion of honesty. There isn't much work on this, so we're focussing on Christian Miller's theory.

item.title: Week Nine: Hypocrisy
item.dc:creator: Brian Weatherson
item.description: We continue our look at individual virtues with a discussion of hypocrisy, focussing on Danielle Dover's "The Walk and the Talk".

item.title: Week Eight: Intellectual Humility
item.dc:creator: Brian Weatherson
item.description: We continue our look at individual virtues with a discussion of intellectual humility. (This is much less worked out than normal - more a series of questions to prompt discussion than a full presentation - hopefully next week we'll resume normal service.)

item.title: Week Three: Williams
item.dc:creator: Brian Weatherson
item.description: A look at the role thick concepts play in Ethics and the Limits of Philosophy, with a special focus on just what distinction in the vague vicinity of the fact/value distinction is viable, and how thick concepts do and don't complicate it.

item.title: Week Two: Moral Arguments
item.dc:creator: Brian Weatherson
item.description: We'll start by looking at Arthur Prior's formal arguments against the 'No Ought from an Is' principle, and some contemporary responses to them. Then the bulk of the time will be looking at Philippa Foot's 1958 paper Moral Arguments. She also objects to 'No Ought from an Is', using a particular thick concept - rudeness - in her main example.

item.title: Week One
item.dc:creator: Brian Weatherson
item.description: I start by introducing some examples of the kinds of terms that will be at the center of our attention for the course. Then I look at some failed attempts to provide a characterisation of this class. I introduce two philosophical disputes that thick terms are central to, one concerning moral motivation, another concerning the nature of moral attitudes. The second has been the most important, so I spend a bit of time going over it, including going back to the origins of 20th century meta-ethics in G. E. Moore's Principia Ethica.
